trans-unit.source: array $local_tasks: The array of local tasks plugin definitions, keyed by plugin ID.
array $loggers: An array of arrays of \Psr\Log\LoggerInterface keyed by priority.
array $main_content: The render array representing the main content.
array $main_content_renderers: The available main content renderer service IDs, keyed by format.
array $manipulators: The menu link tree manipulators to apply. Each is an array with keys:

array $map: An associative array whose keys are element property names and whose values are the HTML attribute names to set on the corresponding property; e.g., array('#propertyname' => 'attributename'). If both names are identical except for the leading '#', then an attribute name value is sufficient and no property name needs to be specified.
array $mapping: An array containing a mandatory 'properties' key and optional 'datatype', 'datatype_callback' and 'type' keys. For example:
array $mappings: (optional) Custom mappings to support user agents that are sending non standard language codes. No mapping is assumed by default.
array $match: An array containing matches to replace from preg_replace_callback(), whereas $match[1] is expected to contain the content to be filtered.
array $matches: An array of matches by preg_replace_callback().
array $matches: An array of matches by a preg_replace_callback() call that scans for @import-ed CSS files, except for external CSS files.
array $matches: An array of matches by a preg_replace_callback() call that scans for url() references in CSS files, except for external or absolute ones.

array $matches: This function is a callback for preg_replace_callback(), which is called from search_simplify(). So, $matches is an array of regular expression matches, which means that $matches[0] contains the matched text -- a string of CJK characters to tokenize.
array $menu_names: (optional) Array of menu names to limit the options, or NULL to load all.
array $menus: (optional) array of menu names as keys and titles as values to limit the values that may be selected. If NULL, all menus will be included.
array $menus: Optional array of menu names as keys and titles as values to limit the select options. If NULL, all menus will be included.
array $message: A message array, as described in hook_mail_alter().
array $message: Message array with at least the following elements:
array $metadata: Additional metadata of contextual links, like the position (optional).
array $methods: An array containing user account cancellation methods, keyed by method id.
array $missing_content: Missing content information.
array $module_filenames: List of module filenames, keyed by module name.

array $module_list: An associative array whose keys are the names of installed modules and whose values are Extension class parameters. This is normally the %container.modules% parameter being set up by DrupalKernel.
array $module_list: The new list of modules.
array $modules: An array of module objects keyed by module name. Each object contains information discovered during a Drupal\Core\Extension\ExtensionDiscovery scan.
array $multipliers: An array with multipliers as keys and image style mappings as values.
array $names: A list of configuration names that are being loaded.
array $names: A list of extension machine names.
array $names: An array of names of configuration objects to update.
array $names: List of configuration object names (which are strings) to update.
array $names: List of names of configuration objects.
array $names: List of names of the configuration objects to load.
array $names: The configuration names.
array $names: The names of the configuration objects to get overrides for.

array $names: The specific names to check. If $type equals 'module' or 'theme' then it should be a list of module names or theme names. In the case of 'config' or 'content' it should be a list of configuration dependency names.
array $namespaces: A list of namespaces.
array $namespaces: Array where each key is a namespace like 'Drupal\system', and each value is either a PSR-4 base directory, or an array of PSR-4 base directories associated with this namespace.
array $namespaces: List of potential namespaces of the classes belonging to this condition.
array $namespaces: List of potential namespaces of the classes belonging to this query.
array $needs_matching: The list of config array keys needing a match. Can contain config keys and the * wildcard.
array $negotiation_info: Array of language negotiation method definitions.
array $nested_insert_values: A nested array of values to insert.
array $new_definition_values: The new values for the link definition. This will usually be just a subset of the plugin definition.
array $nids: (optional) An array of entity IDs. If omitted, all entities are loaded.
array $nids: An array of node IDs.
array $node_links: Stores references to menu link elements to effectively set access.
array $nodes An array of named nodes:
array $nodes: An array of node IDs.
array $nodes: Array of node nids or nodes to update.
array $objects: An array of entities.
array $operations: An array of function calls (not used in this function).
array $operations: Operations array as returned by \Drupal\Core\Entity\EntityListBuilderInterface::getOperations().
array $options: (optional) A keyed array of settings and flags to control the token replacement process. Supported options are:
array $options: (optional) A keyed array of settings. Supported options are:
array $options: (optional) An array of database options.
array $options: (optional) An array of options on the query.
array $options: (optional) An array of options to control how the query operates.
array $options: (optional) An array of options. See Url::fromUri() for details.
array $options: (optional) An array with options that can have the following elements:
array $options: (optional) An associative array of additional URL options, with the following elements:
array $options: (optional) An associative array of additional options, with the following elements:
array $options: (optional) An associative array of additional options.
array $options: (optional) An associative array of additional options. See t() for allowed keys.
array $options: (optional) An associative array of additional options. See \Drupal\Core\Url for the available keys.
array $options: (optional) An associative array of additional options. The 'absolute' option is forced to be FALSE.
array $options: (optional) An associative array of additional options. The 'absolute' option is forced to be TRUE.
array $options: (optional) An associative array of options to control how the query is run. See the documentation for DatabaseConnection::defaultOptions() for details.
array $options: (optional) An associative array of options to control how the query is run. See the documentation for DatabaseConnection::defaultOptions() for details.
array $options: (optional) An associative array with additional options. The following keys can be used:
array $options: (optional) Any additional database connection options to use in queries.
array $options: (optional) Collection-specific storage override options.
array $options: (optional) The URL options. Defaults to none.
array $options: A keyed array of settings and flags to control the token replacement process. See \Drupal\Core\Utility\Token::replace().
array $options: A keyed array of settings and flags to control the token replacement process. Supported options are:

array $options: An array of display options. Refer to \Drupal\Core\Field\FieldDefinitionInterface::getDisplayOptions() for a list of supported keys. The options should include at least a 'weight', or specify 'type' = 'hidden'. The 'default_widget' / 'default_formatter' for the field type will be used if no 'type' is specified.
array $options: An array of options that can be used to determine a suitable plugin to instantiate and how to configure it.
array $options: An array of options to control how the query operates.
array $options: An array of options to control how the transaction operates:
array $options: An array of options to control which connection is closed. Only the target key has any meaning in this case.
array $options: An array of options with the following keys:
array $options: An array of options, see \Drupal\Core\Url::fromUri() for details.
array $options: An array of options.
array $options: An array with options that can have the following elements:
array $options: An array with options:
array $options: An array with the following key/value pairs:
array $options: An associative array of additional options, with the following elements:
array $options: An associative array of additional options. See t() for allowed keys.
array $options: An associative array of options for token replacement; see \Drupal\Core\Utility\Token::replace() for possible values.
array $options: An associative array of options to control how the query is run.

array $options: An associative array of options to control how the query is run. The given options will be merged with self::defaultOptions(). See the documentation for self::defaultOptions() for details. Typically, $options['return'] will be set by a default or by a query builder, and should not be set by a user.
array $options: An associative array of session ini settings.
array $options: Array of database options.
array $options: Array of import options.
array $options: Array of import options. See locale_translate_batch_import_files().
array $options: Array of query options.
array $options: Batch processing options.
array $options: Optional array of options to set on the \Drupal\Core\Url object.
array $options: See \Drupal\Core\Routing\UrlGeneratorInterface::generateFromRoute() for the available options.
array $options: See \Drupal\Core\Url::fromUri() for details.
array $options: The array of flattened options.

array $options: The array of options for the field, as returned by \Drupal\Core\TypedData\OptionsProviderInterface::getSettableOptions(). An empty option (_none) might have been added, depending on the field properties.
array $options: The array of options. See \Drupal\Core\Url::fromUri() for details on what it contains.
array $options: The display options.
array $options: The options for the Twig environment.
array $options: The options to merge in the defaults.
array $options: The select options.

array $options: These options are used to generate JavaScript settings necessary to configure the tableDrag behavior appropriately for this particular table. An associative array containing the following keys:
array $original: The link definition before the changes. May be empty if not found.
array $original: The original menu link.
array $original: The parent definition used to find the depth.
array $original_data: Original data array to filter against.
array $override_data: Override data to filter.
array $overrides: An array of overrides for the default parameters.
array $overrides: An array of settings to override defaults; see self::getInstallArgs().

array $overrides: Associative array of language-specific overrides whose keys are integer Unicode character codes, and whose values are the transliterations of those characters in the given language, to override default transliterations.
array $overrides: Specifies the overrides, this is an array where the key is the asset to be overridden while the value is overriding asset.
array $page_additions: Additional regions to add to the page. May also be used to pass the #show_messages property for #type 'page'.
array $page_bottom: A renderable array representing the bottom of the page.
array $page_top: A renderable array representing the top of the page.
array $pager: A renderable array of #type => pager.
array $parameters An array of parameters for the message:
array $parameters An array with the parameter names as keys and: the values to be inserted in their place as values
array $parameters The parameters substituted in the error message:
array $parameters which should contain a content field containing: a RouteReferrersReadInterface object
array $parameters: An array of parameters as passed to \Symfony\Component\Routing\Generator\UrlGeneratorInterface::generate().
array $parameters: An array of parameters to be passed to the route compiler.
array $parameters: An array of parameters to be passed to the route compiler. Passed by reference.
array $parameters: An array of parameters.
array $parameters: An associative array of parameter names and values.
array $parameters: An associative array of route parameter names and values.
array $parameters: An associative array of route parameters names and values.
array $parameters: Optional array of values to substitute into the route path pattern.
array $parameters: The array of parameters.
array $parameters: The message parameters.
array $parameters: The parameters array.
array $parameters: The parameters to escape for '%' characters.
array $parameters: The route parameters passed to the generator. Parameters that do not match any variables will be added to the result as query parameters.
array $params: (optional) Parameters to build the email.
array $parents: An array of parent keys of the value, starting with the outermost key.
array $parents: An array of parent keys, starting with the outermost key and including the key to be unset.
array $parents: An array of parent keys, starting with the outermost key.
array $parents: An array of the menu link ID values that are in the path from the current page to the root of the menu tree.
array $parents: One or more parent IDs to match.
array $parents: The array of #parents where the field lives in the form.
array $parents: The array of #parents where the widget lives in the form.
array $parents: The current list of parents.
array $parts: All the parts of a configuration key we are checking.
array $parts: Array to check input against, ignoring elements not in this array.
array $parts: The parts of the path for which we want candidates.
array $path: The array structure is identical to that of the return value of \Drupal\Core\Path\PathInterface::save().
array $pathVariables: An array of path variables
array $paths: A list of installation profile directory paths relative to the system root directory (without trailing slash) to search for extensions.
array $permissions: (optional) A list of permission names to grant.
array $permissions: (optional) A list of permission names to revoke.

array $permissions: (optional) An associative array, where the key holds the permission name and the value determines whether to grant or revoke that permission. Any value that evaluates to TRUE will cause the permission to be granted. Any value that evaluates to FALSE will cause the permission to be revoked.
array $permissions: The permissions to check.
array $placeholders: An array of placeholders, keyed by type with the placeholders present in the content of the response as values.
array $placeholders: The placeholders that exist in the response.
array $plugin_definition: The plugin implementation definition.
array $plugin_id: The plugin_id for the widget.
array $plugins: An array of all the existing handler definitions, passed by reference.
array $plugins: An array of all the existing plugin definitions, passed by reference.

array $pre_bubbling_elements: A renderable array corresponding to the state (in particular, the cacheability metadata) of $elements prior to the beginning of its rendering process, and therefore before any bubbling of child information has taken place. Only the #cache property is used by this function, so the caller may omit all other properties and children from this array.

array $pre_bubbling_elements: A renderable array corresponding to the state (in particular, the cacheability metadata) of $rendered_elements prior to the beginning of its rendering process, and therefore before any bubbling of child information has taken place. Only the #cache property is used by this function, so the caller may omit all other properties and children from this array.
array $prefixes: An array of prefixes to test, in reverse order of importance.
array $preloaded: Paths that need preloading of aliases.
array $project_names: Array of names of the projects to get.
array $project_results: An associative array of results from the batch operation.
array $projects: (optional) Project names from which to delete the translation files and history. Defaults to all projects.
array $projects: (optional) Project names from which to get the translation files and history. Defaults to all projects.
array $projects: Array of project names for which to check the state of translation files. Defaults to all translatable projects.
array $projects: Array of project names for which to update the translations. Defaults to all translatable projects.
array $projects: Array of project names to be processed.
array $projects: Array of project names to check. Defaults to all translatable projects.
array $projects: Array of project names. Defaults to all translatable projects.
array $projects: Project data as returned by \Drupal\Update\UpdateManager::getProjects().
array $projects: Project name(s) to be deleted from the cache.
array $projects: Project name(s) to be deleted from the file history. If both project(s) and language code(s) are specified the conditions will be ANDed.
array $projects: Reference to the array of project data of what's installed on this site.
array $properties: The properties to filter by.
array $protocols: An array of protocols, for example http, https and irc.
array $query: (optional) The query (GET) or request (POST) parameters.
array $query: An array to be processed.
array $query: An associative array of URL query parameters to add to.
array $query: The query parameter array to be processed; for instance, \Drupal::request()->query->all().
array $query: The query string for the current URL.
array $query_params: An array of query string parameter, which will get any extra values from $parameters merged in.
array $query_params: Query parameters passed to the generator as $options['query'].
array $queues: An array of cron queue information.
array $raw_parameters: The raw $parameters array.
array $rebuild_info: The rebuild info.
array $records: Associative array of query results, keyed on the entity ID.
array $render_array: A render array.
array $rendered_elements: A fully rendered renderable array.
array $renderer_config: The renderer configuration array.
array $replace: An associative array. The keys are the old permissions the values are lists of new permissions. If the list is an empty array, the old permission is removed.
array $replacements: An array of replacements for dynamic type names.
array $replacements: An associative array variable containing mappings from token names to values (for use with strtr()).
array $request: (optional) An array of request variables.
array $requirements: An array of requirements, in the same format as is returned by hook_requirements().
array $results: An array of results information.
array $results: Batch results.
array $results: Information about the results of the batch import.
array $roles: An array of role IDs.
array $route_parameters.: The route parameters passed to each route_name of the contextual links. For example:
array $route_parameters:
array $route_parameters: (optional) An associative array of parameter names and values.
array $route_parameters: (optional) An associative array of route parameter names and values.
array $route_parameters: (optional) Parameters for the route.
array $route_parameters: (optional) The route parameters. Defaults to an empty array.
array $route_parameters: The incoming route parameters. The route parameters need to have the same name on all contextual link routes, e.g. you cannot use 'node' and 'entity' in parallel.
array $rows: An associative array with two keys:
array $sandbox: Stores information for batch updates. See above for more information.
array $scalars: An associative array of parameter names to scalar candidate values.
array $schema: Drupal schema definition.
array $schema: A reference to the schema array to be updated.
array $schema: The entity schema array.
array $schema: The entity schema data array.
array $schema: The field schema data array.
array $schema: The schema definition array as it was returned by the module's hook_schema().
array $schema: The table schema, passed by reference.
array $schema: The table specification.
array $schema_only: Table patterns for which to only dump the schema, no data.
array $selection_settings: An array of settings that will be passed to the selection handler.
array $server: (optional) The server parameters ($_SERVER).
array $service:
array $settings:
array $settings: (optional) A keyed array for settings, suitable for passing on to __construct().
array $settings: (optional) Keyed array of settings. Defaults to empty array.
array $settings: @see __construct()
array $settings: All the settings that will be added to the page for the text formats to which a user has access.
array $settings: An array of JavaScript settings to be passed to any attached behaviors.
array $settings: An array of connection settings for the FileTransfer subclass. If the getSettingsForm() method uses any nested settings, the same structure will be assumed here.
array $settings: An array of connection settings for the FileTransfer subclass. If the getSettingsForm() method uses any nested settings, the same structure will be assumed here.
array $settings: An array of key/value pairs of JavaScript settings.
array $settings: Array with the settings.
array $settings: The array of field settings.
array $settings: The array of settings.
array $settings: The field's settings in the field type's canonical representation.
array $settings: The field's settings, as it is stored within a configuration object.
array $settings: The formatter settings.
array $settings: The needed JavaScript settings.
array $settings: The widget settings.
array $sort_order: Array to sort that can be used to sort the changelist. This array must contain all the items that are in the change list.

array $spec: The field specification array, as taken from a schema definition. The specification may also contain the key 'initial'; the newly-created field will be set to the value of the key in all rows. This is most useful for creating NOT NULL columns with no default value in existing tables.
array $spec: The field specification, as per the schema data structure format.

array $spec: The table specification for the table to be altered. This is used in order to be able to ensure that the index length is not too long. This schema definition can usually be obtained through hook_schema(), or in case the table was created by the Entity API, through the schema handler listed in the entity class definition. For reference, see SqlContentEntityStorageSchema::getDedicatedTableSchema() and SqlContentEntityStorageSchema::getSharedTableFieldSchema().
array $spec: The table specification of the table to be altered, as taken from a schema definition. See \Drupal\Core\Database\Schema::addIndex() for how to obtain this specification.
array $spec: The table specification.
array $specifier: The fields to index.
array $specifier: The unique fields.
array $storage: The entire set of arbitrary data to store for this form.
array $sub_key: An array containing the sub-keys specifying the library asset, e.g.
array $submit_handlers: An array of submit handlers.
array $suffixes: An array of suffixes. Will be cast to strings.
array $suggestions: An array of alternate, more specific names for template files or theme functions.
array $suggestions: An array of theme suggestions.
array $summary: An array of summary messages.

array $sync_steps: A one-dimensional array of \Drupal\Core\Config\ConfigImporter method names or callables that are invoked to complete the import, in the order that they will be processed. Each callable item defined in $sync_steps should either be a global function or a public static method. The callable should accept a $context array by reference. For example: <code> function _additional_configuration_step(&$context) { // Do stuff. // If finished set $context['finished'] = 1. } </code> For more information on creating batches, see the Batch operations documentation.
array $table: A Schema API table definition array.
array $tags: (optional) The tags to specify for the cache item.

array $tags: An array of tags to be stored with the cache item. These should normally identify objects used to build the cache item, which should trigger cache invalidation when updated. For example if a cached item represents a node, both the node ID and the author's user ID might be passed in as tags. For example array('node' => array(123), 'user' => array(92)).
array $tags: An array of tags.
array $tags: The array of tags to calculate the checksum for.
array $temporary: Temporary data accessible during the current page request only.
array $terms: An array of taxonomy terms as returned by Term::loadMultiple().
array $theme_list: An array of theme names.
array $theme_list: Array containing the names of the themes being installed.
array $theme_list: Array containing the names of the themes being uninstalled.
array $theme_list: The themes to uninstall.
array $theme_settings: An array of theme settings from system setting form or a Drupal 7 variable.
array $themes: An array of available themes.
array $third_party_settings: Any third party settings.
array $tids: (optional) An array of entity IDs. If omitted, all entities are loaded.
array $tokens: Token metadata that has an identical structure to the return value of hook_token_info().
array $tokens: A keyed array of tokens, and their original raw form in the source text.
array $tokens: An array of tokens to be replaced, keyed by the literal text of the token as it appeared in the source text.
array $tokens: An array of tokens to use to generate URL for this route
array $tokens: The tokens from the compiled route.
array $tour_tips: Array of \Drupal\tour\TipPluginInterface items.
array $translations: Array of override strings indexed by language and context
array $tree: A menu link tree from MenuTreeStorage::doBuildTreeData()
array $tree: The menu tree you wish to operate on.
array $ts: The current table sort context as returned from tablesort_init().
array $uids: (optional) An array of entity IDs. If omitted, all entities are loaded.
array $updaters: Associative array of updaters as defined through hook_updater_info(). Alter this array directly.
array $updates: Array of key/value pairs with node field names and the value to update that field to.
array $updates: Associative array of updates.
array $uri_parts: Parts from an URI of the form entity:{entity_type}/{entity_id} as from parse_url().
array $uri_parts: Parts from an URI of the form internal:{path} as from parse_url().

array $uri_parts: Parts from an URI of the form route:{route_name};{route_parameters} as from parse_url(), where the path is the route name optionally followed by a ";" followed by route parameters in key=value format with & separators.
array $used_themes: (optional) A recursion parameter preventing endless loops. Defaults to an empty array.
array $user_input: An associative array of raw and unvalidated values.
array $uuids: An array of file entity UUIDs.
array $validate_handlers: An array of validate handlers.

array $validators: (optional) An associative array of callback functions used to validate the file. See file_validate() for a full discussion of the array format. If the array is empty, it will be set up to call file_validate_extensions() with a safe list of extensions, as follows: "jpg jpeg gif png txt doc xls pdf ppt pps odt ods odp". To allow all extensions, you must explicitly set this array to ['file_validate_extensions' => '']. (Beware: this is not safe and should only be allowed for trusted users, if at all.)

array $validators: (optional) An associative array of callback functions used to validate the file. The keys are function names and the values arrays of callback parameters which will be passed in after the file entity. The functions should return an array of error messages; an empty array indicates that the file passed validation. The callback functions will be called in the order specified in the array, then the hook hook_file_validate() will be invoked so other modules can validate the new file.
array $values: (optional) An array of fields to insert into the database. The values must be specified in the same order as the $fields array.
array $values: (optional) An array of initial values to be assigned to the translatable fields. Defaults to none.
array $values: (optional) An array of values to set, keyed by property name. If the entity type has bundles, the bundle key has to be specified.
array $values: (optional) An associative array of initial field values keyed by field name. If none is provided default values will be applied.
array $values: (optional) If given, an array of initial values to set on the definition.
array $values: (optional) The configuration entity's values.
array $values: An array of base field bundle override properties, keyed by property name. The field to override is specified by referring to an existing field with:
array $values: An array of key/value pairs to be saved into a cookie.
array $values: An array of property values, keyed by property name, used to construct the language.
array $values: An array of values to add to the query.
array $values: An array of values to set, keyed by property name.
array $values: An array of values to set, keyed by property name. If the entity type has bundles, the bundle key has to be specified.
array $values: An associative array of properties of the entity, where the keys are the property names and the values are the values those properties must have.
array $values: An associative array where the keys are the property names and the values are the values those properties must have.
array $values: An associative array with the following keys:
array $values: Array of initial values for the user session.
array $values: Possible array keys:
array $values: The array of values from the configuration storage.
array $values: The block config values.
array $values: The multi-dimensional associative array of form values.
array $values: The properties of the object, keyed by the names.
array $values: The properties used to construct the default language.
array $values: The submitted form values produced by the widget.
array $values: Values for the menu link.

array $variables: A keyed array of variables that are available for composing the output. The theme engine is responsible for passing all the variables to the template. Depending on the code in the template, all or just a subset of the variables might be used in the template.
array $variables: A keyed array of variables that will appear in the output.
array $variables: An array containing the following elements:
array $variables: An array of variables (variables defined in the path and in the host patterns)
array $variables: An array of variables passed to the theme hook. Note that this hook is invoked before any preprocessing.
array $variables: An array of variables passed to the theme hook. Note that this hook is invoked before any variable preprocessing.
array $variables: An array with the following elements:
array $variables: An array with the following keys:
array $variables: An associative array containing the following key:
array $variables: An associative array containing the following keys:
array $variables: An associative array containing:
array $variables: An associative array of default template variables, as set up by _template_preprocess_default_variables(). Passed by reference.
array $variables: An associative array of theme variables.

array $variables: An associative array of variables defining a link. The link may be either a "route link" using \Drupal\Core\Utility\LinkGenerator::link(), which is exposed as the 'link_generator' service or a link generated by \Drupal\Core\Utility\LinkGeneratorInterface::generate(). If the link is a "route link", 'route_name' will be set; otherwise, 'path' will be set. The following keys can be altered:
array $variables: An associative array possibly containing:
array $variables: The variables form the compiled route, corresponding to slugs in the route path.
array $variables: The variables to render and replace, keyed by type with renderable arrays as values.
array $vids: (optional) An array of entity IDs. If omitted, all entities are loaded.
array $view_element: The render array of the view. It should contain the following properties:
array $view_modes: An array of view modes, keyed first by entity type, then by view mode name.
array $violations: The array of violations.
array $weekdays: An array of weekdays.
array $weights: An array of weights, keyed by originating directory.
array &$attachments: An array that you can add attachments to.
array &$attachments: Array of all attachments provided by hook_page_attachments() implementations.
array &$build: A render array.
array &$build: A renderable array containing the entity's caching and view mode values.
array &$build: A renderable array of data, as returned from the build() implementation of the plugin that defined the block:
array &$build: A renderable array of data, only containing #cache.
array &$build: A renderable array representing the entity content.

base hook: Used for theme suggestions only: the base theme hook name. Instead of this suggestion's implementation being used directly, the base hook will be invoked with this implementation as its first suggestion. The base hook's files will be included and the base hook's preprocess functions will be called in place of any suggestion's preprocess functions. If an implementation of hook_theme_suggestions_HOOK() (where HOOK is the base hook) changes the suggestion order, a different suggestion may be used in place of this suggestion. If after hook_theme_suggestions_HOOK() this suggestion remains the first suggestion, then this suggestion's function or template will be used to generate the rendered output.
base theme: Name of a base theme, if applicable.
base_class: The base class name.
base_form_id: Identification for a base form, as declared in the form class's \Drupal\Core\Form\BaseFormIdInterface::getBaseFormId() method.
base_path: The base URL path of the Drupal installation. Will usually be "/" unless you have installed Drupal in a sub-directory.
base_route: The machine name of the main task (tab) for the set of local tasks.
base_theme: If this is a sub-theme, the machine name of the base theme defined in the .info.yml file. Otherwise, the element is not set.

base_themes: If this is a sub-theme, an associative array of the base-theme ancestors of this theme, starting with this theme's base theme, then the base theme's own base theme, etc. Each entry has an array key equal to the theme's machine name, and a value equal to the human-readable theme name; if a theme with matching machine name does not exist in the system, the value will instead be NULL (and since the system would not know whether that theme itself has a base theme, that will end the array of base themes). This is not set if the theme is not a sub-theme.
base_url: URL to the home page.

batch: This indicates that the task function will return a batch API definition suitable for batch_set() or an array of batch definitions suitable for consecutive batch_set() calls. The installer will then take care of automatically running the task via batch processing.
before: Label goes before the element (default for most elements).

body: An array of lines containing the message to be sent. Drupal will format the correct line endings for you. MailManagerInterface->mail() sets this to an empty array when the hook is invoked. The array may contain either strings or objects implementing \Drupal\Component\Render\MarkupInterface.
body: Message to be sent. Accepts both CRLF and LF line-endings. Email bodies must be wrapped. For smart plain text wrapping you can use \Drupal\Core\Mail\MailFormatHelper::wrapMail() .

bool $complete: Optional boolean to indicate whether to return the complete theme registry array or an instance of the Drupal\Core\Utility\ThemeRegistry class. If TRUE, the complete theme registry array will be returned. This is useful if you want to foreach over the whole registry, use array_* functions or inspect it in a debugger. If FALSE, an instance of the Drupal\Core\Utility\ThemeRegistry class will be returned, this provides an ArrayObject which allows it to be accessed with array syntax and isset(), and should be more lightweight than the full registry. Defaults to TRUE.

bool $notify: (optional) Whether to notify the parent object of the change. Defaults to TRUE. If the update stems from a parent object, set it to FALSE to avoid being notified again.

bool $optimize: Whether to apply the JavaScript asset collection optimizer, to return optimized JavaScript asset collections rather than an unoptimized ones.

bool $remove_descriptions: (optional) Whether to additionally remove 'description' keys of all tables and fields to improve performance of serialize() and unserialize(). Defaults to TRUE.
bool $repeat: (optional) If this is FALSE and the message is already set, then the message won't be repeated. Defaults to FALSE.

bool $require_settings: Only directories with an existing settings.php file will be recognized. Defaults to TRUE. During initial installation, this is set to FALSE so that Drupal can detect a matching directory, then create a new settings.php file in it.
bool $required: (optional) If FALSE, the returned array will include a blank value. Defaults to FALSE.
bool $required: TRUE if the field is required. FALSE otherwise.
bool $required: TRUE if validation is required, FALSE otherwise.
bool $required: Whether the data is required.
bool $reset: (optional) If set to TRUE static cache will be ignored and a new schema array generation will be performed. Defaults to FALSE.
bool $reset: (optional) Whether to reset the node_load_multiple() cache. Defaults to FALSE.
bool $reset: (optional) Whether to reset the internal file_load_multiple() cache. Defaults to FALSE.
bool $reset: (optional) Whether to reset the internal node_load() cache. Defaults to FALSE.
bool $reset: (optional) Whether to reset the internal file_load_multiple() cache. Defaults to FALSE.
bool $reset: (optional) Whether to reset the render cache for the requested entities. Defaults to FALSE.
bool $reset: (optional) Whether to reset the render cache for the requested entity. Defaults to FALSE.
bool $reset: A boolean indicating that the internal cache should be reset. Use this if loading a user object which has been altered during the page request.
bool $reset: Set to TRUE after installing or uninstalling an extension.
bool $reset: TRUE to reset the internal cache and load from the database; FALSE (default) to load from the internal cache, if set.
bool $reset: Whether to reset the internal cache for the requested entity type.
bool $return_as_object: (optional) Defaults to FALSE.
bool $revision: TRUE for revision table, FALSE otherwise.
bool $revisionable: Whether the field is revisionable.
bool $revisions: (optional) TRUE if $nodes contains an array of revision IDs instead of node IDs. Defaults to FALSE; will be ignored if $load is FALSE.

bool $send: If TRUE, call an implementation of \Drupal\Core\Mail\MailInterface->mail() to deliver the message, and store the result in $message['result']. Modules implementing hook_mail_alter() may cancel sending by setting $message['send'] to FALSE.
bool $session_writable: Whether or not the session should be initially writable.
bool $shared: (optional) Whether the service will be shared with others. By default this parameter is FALSE.
bool $sort: Boolean to indicate whether the children should be sorted by weight.
bool $status: Boolean that controls what status (enabled or uninstalled) to process out of the $list and add to the $projects array.
bool $status: The status of the configuration entity.
bool $status: The status of the sync flag.
bool $strict: Whether to trigger a form error if an element from $input (eg. an entity) is not found.
bool $strip_chroot: Whether to remove the path in $this->chroot.
bool $success: (optional) TRUE if the operation the message is about was a success, FALSE if there were errors. Defaults to TRUE.
bool $success: A boolean indicating whether the batch mass update operation successfully concluded.
bool $success: A boolean indicating whether the re-build process has completed.
bool $success: Information about the success of the batch import.
bool $success: TRUE if batch successfully completed.
bool $title_attribute: (optional) If TRUE, add the link description as the title attribute if the description is not empty.
bool $translatable: Whether the field is translatable.
bool $translatable: Whether the field supports translation.

bool $uninstall_dependents: (optional) If TRUE, dependent modules will automatically be uninstalled in the correct order. This incurs a significant performance cost, so use FALSE if you know $module_list is already complete.
bool $unique: (optional) If TRUE ensures that the random string returned is unique. Defaults to FALSE.
bool $update: Specifies whether the entity is being updated or created.
bool $update: TRUE if the entity has been updated, or FALSE if it has been inserted.
bool $update: TRUE if the entity is being updated, FALSE if it is being inserted.
bool $upscale: (optional) Boolean indicating that files smaller than the dimensions will be scaled up. This generally results in a low quality image.
bool $upscale: (optional) Boolean indicating that images smaller than the target dimensions will be scaled up. This generally results in a low quality image.
bool $use_caches: FALSE to not use any caches.
bool $use_file_cache: Whether file cache should be used.
bool $validation_complete: TRUE if validation is complete, FALSE otherwise.
bool $value: (optional) Whether a new revision should be saved.
bool $value: (optional) Whether the entity should be forced to be new. Defaults to TRUE.

bool $wordsafe: If TRUE, attempt to truncate on a word boundary. Word boundaries are spaces, punctuation, and Unicode characters used as word boundaries in non-Latin languages; see Unicode::PREG_CLASS_WORD_BOUNDARY for more information. If a word boundary cannot be found that would make the length of the returned string fall within length guidelines (see parameters $max_length and $min_wordsafe_length), word boundaries are ignored.

bool &$cacheable: (optional) If an $entity is provided, the $cacheable parameter should be modified by reference and set to FALSE if the set of allowed values returned was specifically adjusted for that entity and cannot not be reused for other entities. Defaults to TRUE.
bool &$resolve: Used for passing the information to the caller whether the given collection needed to be resolved or not. This is used for optimizing deep arrays that don't need to be traversed.
bool|NULL $include_tests: (optional) A flag whether to include tests in the scanning of modules.
bool|null $affected: The flag value. A NULL value can be specified to reset the current value and make sure a new value will be computed by the system.
bool|null $case_sensitive: If the condition should be case sensitive or not, NULL if the field does not define it.
bool|null $escape: (optional) A Boolean indicating whether to escape (TRUE) or unescape comments (FALSE). Defaults to NULL, indicating neither. If TRUE, statically cached $comments are reset.
bool|true $tryProxy:
bootstrap: Data needed from the beginning to the end of most requests, that has a very strict limit on variations and is invalidated rarely.
breadcrumb: Breadcrumb trail items.
build: Table of content language settings.
builder: the instance of \Drupal\Core\Breadcrumb\BreadcrumbBuilderInterface that constructed this breadcrumb, or NULL if no builder acted based on the current attributes.

bundle: (optional) The name of the property that contains the bundle name for the entity. The bundle name defines which set of fields are attached to the entity (e.g. what nodes call "content type"). This entry can be omitted if this entity type exposes a single bundle (such that all entities have the same collection of fields). The name of this single bundle will be the same as the entity type.
bundle: Machine name of the current vocabulary.
bundle: The bundle, e.g., 'page' or 'article'.
bundles: A list of bundles, each with the following properties:
bundles: An array of bundles with the label, description, add_link keys.

bundles: The bundles in which the field appears.
button: "Add another item" button.
by-anonymous: Comment by an unregistered user.
by-{entity-type}-author: Comment by the author of the parent entity, eg. by-node-author.
cache.bin: Indicates a cache bin service; see the Cache topic for more information.
cache_bypass: A timestamp token used to avoid browser caching of images.
call: The method name to call on the consumer service. Defaults to 'addHandler'. The called method receives two arguments:
callable $callable: The callable (either a function or a method).
callable $callable: The callable to execute.

callable $callback: The callback to be executed.

callable $controller: The controller to execute.
callable $validator: (optional) A callable to validate the string. Defaults to NULL.
callable $value_callable: The callable to be checked.
callable: a callable or a string that can be resolved to a callable by \Drupal\Core\Controller\ControllerResolverInterface::getControllerFromDefinition()
callable|NULL $callable: The callable to apply for filtering.
callback: A callback function that will be used to post-process the array of token replacements after they are generated.

callback: A callback function that will be used to post-process the array of token replacements after they are generated. Can be used when modules require special formatting of token text, for example URL encoding or truncation to a specific length.
callback: The actual callback to be used to retrieve the form array. Can be any callable. If none is provided $form_id is used as the name of a function to call instead.
callback: The callback to invoke to handle the server side of the Ajax event. More information on callbacks is below in Setting up a callback to process Ajax.
canonical: Default link, either to view (if entities are viewed on their own pages) or edit the entity.
canonical: This key (in the 'links' entity info property) must be defined if the entity path is different from /ENTITY_TYPE/{ENTITY_TYPE}
caption: A localized string for the <caption> tag.
caption: A localized string to use for the <caption> tag.
caption: The caption for this table.
caption_needed: Is the caption tag needed.
cells: Table cells of the row. Each cell contains the following keys:
changed: Formatted date and time for when the comment was last changed. Preprocess functions can reformat it by calling format_date() with the desired parameters on the 'comment.changed' variable.
channel_elements: The formatted channel elements.
checkbox: A checkbox for enabling the module.
checkbox: A checkbox for uninstalling the module.
checkbox_id: A unique identifier for interacting with the checkbox element.

children: All the child nodes recursively rendered through this file.
children: All the rendered child nodes within the current node. Defaults to an empty string.
children: Contains the child elements of the dropbutton menu.

children: Remaining form items for all groups.
children: Remaining form items for the group.
children: Text format element children.
children: The child elements of the form.
children: The remaining elements such as dropbuttons and tabs.
children: The rendered checkboxes.
children: The rendered child elements of the <fieldset>.
children: The rendered child elements of the container.
children: The rendered radios.
children: The rendered tabs.
class: (optional) A custom ContextDefinitionInterface class.

class: An array of values for the 'class' attribute. In particular, the least important columns that can be hidden on narrow and medium width screens should have a 'priority-low' class, referenced with the RESPONSIVE_PRIORITY_LOW constant. Columns that should be shown on medium+ wide screens should be marked up with a class of 'priority-medium', referenced by with the RESPONSIVE_PRIORITY_MEDIUM constant. Themes may hide columns with one of these two classes on narrow viewports to save horizontal space.
class: HTML classes that can be used to style contextually through CSS.
class: HTML classes that determine which icon to display. May be one of 'hot', 'hot-new', 'new', 'default', 'closed', or 'sticky'.
class: HTML classes to be applied to the feed link.
class: HTML classes.
class: One or more classes to be applied to the image.

class: The name of a class that implements \Drupal\Core\Queue\QueueInterface, including the full namespace but not starting with a backslash. It must have a constructor with two arguments: $name and a \Drupal\Core\Database\Connection object. Typically, the class will either be \Drupal\Core\Queue\Batch or \Drupal\Core\Queue\BatchMemory. Defaults to Batch if progressive is TRUE, or to BatchMemory if progressive is FALSE.
class: The name of the PHP class which implements this updater.
class: The safe class ID to use.
class: stream wrapper class name
clear: A boolean flag indicating that tokens should be removed from the final text if no replacement value can be generated.
col_class_default: A flag indicating whether default classes should be used on columns.
colgroups: An array of column groups. Each element of the array can be either:
colgroups: Column groups. Each group contains the following properties:
collapsed: The menu item has a submenu that is not shown.

column_groups: contains information about the field type properties which columns should be synchronized across different translations and which are translatable. This is useful for instance to translate the "alt" and "title" textual elements of an image field, while keeping the same image on every translation. Each group has the following keys:
columns: (optional) A list of columns of this group. Defaults to the name of he group as the single column.

columns: An array of Schema API column specifications, keyed by column name. The columns need to be a subset of the properties defined in propertyDefinitions(). The 'not null' property is ignored if present, as it is determined automatically by the storage controller depending on the table layout and the property definitions. It is recommended to avoid having the column definitions depend on field settings when possible. No assumptions should be made on how storage engines internally use the original column name to structure their storage.

columns: An array of Schema API column specifications, keyed by column name. This specifies what comprises a single value for a given field. No assumptions should be made on how storage backends internally use the original column name to structure their storage.
columns: Row column items. Columns are keyed by column number.
comment: Full comment object.
comment: The current template type; for instance, 'theming hook'.
comment_display_mode: Is the comments are threaded.
comment_form: The 'Add new comment' form.
comment_mode: An integer indicating whether comments are open, closed, or hidden.
comment_parent: Full parent comment entity (if any).
comment_type: The comment type bundle ID for the comment field.
comments: List of comments rendered through comment.html.twig.
compact: Boolean indicating whether compact mode is turned on or not.

config_prefix: A string denoting the owner (module/extension) of the configuration object, followed by arbitrary other namespace identifiers that are declared by the owning extension; e.g., 'node.type'. The config_prefix does NOT contain a trailing dot. It is defined by the entity type's annotation.
configurable: A radio element to toggle the table.
configuration: A list of the block's configuration values.

configuration: An array of configuration option definitions, keyed by option name. Each option definition is a typed data definition describing the configuration option. Check the typed data definition docs for details.
containers: A list of administrative containers keyed by position: left or right. Each container in the list contains:
containers: An list of administrative blocks keyed by position: left or right. Contains:
content: (optional) The content of the block.
content: A description of the form element, may not be set.

content: A list containing information about the block. Each element of the array represents an administrative menu item, and must at least contain the keys 'title', 'link_path', and 'localized_options', which are passed to l(). A 'description' key may also be provided.
content: A list of columns or rows. Each row or column contains:

content: A list of content items. Use 'content' to print all content, or print a subset such as 'content.field_example'. Fields attached to a user such as 'user_picture' are available as 'content.user_picture'.
content: A localized string for the title of the column.

content: All field items. Use {{ content }} to print them all, or print a subset such as {{ content.field_example }}. Use {{ content|without('field_example') }} to temporarily suppress the printing of a given element.

content: All node items. Use {{ content }} to print them all, or print a subset such as {{ content.field_example }}. Use {{ content|without('field_example') }} to temporarily suppress the printing of a given child element.

content: An array containing information about the block. Each element of the array represents an administrative menu item, and must at least contain the keys 'title', 'link_path', and 'localized_options', which are passed to l(). A 'description' key may also be provided.

content: An array of content types.
content: Content items such as fields or settings in this container.
content: HTML classes to apply to each header cell, indexed by

content: The datelist form element to be output.

content: The row's contents.

content_attributes: List of classes for the styling of the comment content.
content_attributes: Same as attributes, except applied to the main content tag that appears in the template.

content_translation_metadata: To implement its business logic the content translation UI relies on various metadata items describing the translation state. The default implementation is provided by \Drupal\content_translation\ContentTranslationMetadataWrapper, which is relying on one field for each metadata item (field definitions are provided by the translation handler). Entity types needing to customize this behavior can specify an alternative class through the 'content_translation_metadata' key in the entity type definition. Every content translation metadata wrapper needs to implement \Drupal\content_translation\ContentTranslationMetadataWrapperInterface.

content_translation_ui_skip: By default, entity types that do not have a canonical link template cannot be enabled for translation. Setting this key to TRUE overrides that. When that key is set, the Content Translation module will not provide any UI for translating the entity type, and the entity type should implement its own UI. For instance, this is useful for entity types that are embedded into others for editing (which would not need a canonical link, but could still support translation).
contents: Nodes within the current outline rendered through book-node-export-html.html.twig.
contents: Output of each book page.
context (optional): a string that describes the context of "value";
context: A list of contextual data associated with the list. May contain:

context: The context the source strings belong to.
context_provider: Indicates a block context provider, used for example by block conditions. It has to implement \Drupal\Core\Plugin\Context\ContextProviderInterface.
count: A flag indicating whether the count should be displayed.
count: A flag indicating whether the row's 'count' should be displayed.

created: timestamp when the item was put into the queue.

date: The date of the release.

default: (optional) When the argument is set to "required" = FALSE, this must be set to a default value. Ignored for "required" = TRUE arguments.
default: A boolean indicating whether the form is being shown as a dummy form to set default values.
default_classes: A flag indicating whether default classes should be used.

defaults: For entity form routes, use _entity_form rather than the generic _controller or _form. The value is composed of the entity type machine name and a form handler type from the entity annotation (see Defining an entity type above more more on handlers and annotation). So, in this example, block.default refers to the 'default' form handler on the block entity type, whose annotation contains:
degrees: Degrees to rotate the image, positive values will rotate the image clockwise, negative values counter-clockwise.
delete form: Define a class that extends \Drupal\Core\Entity\EntityConfirmFormBase to provide a delete confirmation form for your entities.
delete-form: Confirmation form to delete the entity.

dependencies: A list of libraries this library depends on.

dependencies: An array of shortnames of other modules that this install profile requires.

description (optional): A translated longer description of the token type.

destination: The value of the current request's 'destination' query parameter, if present. This can be either a relative or absolute URL. However, for security, redirection to external URLs is not performed. If the query parameter isn't present, then the URL of the current request is returned.

display: This is a boolean which can be used to provide finer-grained control over whether or not the task will display. This is mostly useful for tasks that are intended to display only under certain conditions; for these tasks, you can set 'display_name' to the name that you want to display, but then use this boolean to hide the task only when certain conditions apply.

display_name: The human-readable name of the task. This will be displayed to the user while the installer is running, along with a list of other tasks that are being run. Leave this unset to prevent the task from appearing in the list.
display_submitted: Whether submission information should be displayed.
displays: List of displays.

distribution: Existence of this key denotes that the installation profile is intended to be the only eligible choice in a distribution and will be auto-selected during installation, whereas the installation profile selection screen will be skipped. If more than one distribution profile is found then the first one discovered will be selected. The following subproperties may be set:
do not have Drupal routes: both external URLs and unrouted local URIs like base:robots.txt
dom_id: Unique id for every view being printed to give unique class for Javascript.
download_link: The URL for the downloadable file.
edit-form: Editing form.

element: An associative array containing the properties of the element. Properties used: #title, #children, #required, #attributes.
